title: What will be the closing value of the S&P 500 Index on 22 September 2020 relative to its closing value on 28 August 2020?
possible_answers: Between down less than 4.0% and up less than 4.0%
preds: We would need a +4% move for the S&P to get into another bucket, which would be a huge outlier from a normal day. There are only 2% of days that are above that threshold usually in a year.
Futures currently up slightly after hours, but we would need 3% up move tomorrow in our to see the 4% bucket.
Based on one day of moves left, it seems unlikely that we see a deviation away from the 4,12 bucket. Leaving in some upside.
Based on implied move to get to third bucket.

Updating before the open on Monday.

On Sep 18th, the SP500 was at 3357.01. Aftermarket indicates a 1.12% drop on Monday opening. For now, the SP500 has dropped 5.37% compared to August 27th. Before Tuesday, the major events driving SP500 includes:
1. Power steaps on Capitol Hill on Tuesday (possibly pushing the markets up if Powell addresses QE uncertainty)
2. Potential new stimulus bill 
3. Tech giants law suits 
4. Sept economic data 
5. Big company earnings (NIKE on the 22nd, etc.)
It is essentially impossible for SP to have a more than 12% move in either direction in this scenario. Unless September turns out to be a strong comeback in terms of Macro economic, is it hard to imagine that the SP will rally more than 2% in the following two days to achieve August's level. Thus, it is mostly likely for SP500 to end up down around 3-7% compared to Aug 28th.  If I were wrong, I most likely made a mistake in: 
1. Miscalculate SP500 daily volatility during current period
2. Volatility events in the same direction happens in a row

Since we are so close to expiry looking at price action and VIX gives me the sense that a one std dev move is within reason to reach the third bucket as such I skew towards mostly 2nd bucket with some in third bucket.

Updating forecast on more negative macroeconomic outlook (lots of economic data came out today) and on tech selloffs (tech might have been overpriced and markets are adjusting now).
Used implied volatility from options to back out  distribution

Volatility likely to be suppressed as markets look for clarity on elections, in my opinion this limits major up/down swings. Risk likely to be skewed towards downside on the back of a strong rally through the past few month and may see a bit of a pull back due to excessive positioning.

Change in the S&P 500 is a highly random process, so I chose to model it with a random walk. I used daily returns over the past month to generate the distribution of changes for each step of the random walk to follow, and simulated the walk 100,000 times. This resulted in the following probabilities. Down more than 12%: 0%
Down between 4% and 12%, inclusive: 12%
Between down less than 4% and up less than 4%: 83%
Up between 4% and 12%, inclusive: 5%
Up more than 12%: 0% However, I was concerned that this method put such little probability on the tail outcomes. I do think that an increase of 12% is vanishingly likely considering the fact that the stock market may already be inflated given the larger economic effects of COVID. But for the same reason I believe a decline of more than 12% is possible, and that a decline between 4% and 12% is more likely than 12%. To account for this I moved 10% away from the middle bucket and distributed it to the bottom two.

Using a similar approach to a TSLA forecasting question, we make use of option deltas to extract probabilities for each of the above buckets. The closest expiry to the date in question, Sept 22, is the Sept 18 calls/puts - however, without a strong prior I plan on taking the option deltas as is. As my colleagues also have done, we first use to closing price on Aug 28th, and convert the percentage changes to numerical closing values of the SPX index; 3087, 3368, 3648, 3929. Using the delta from options closest to these strikes, I arrive at the above distribution.

Cutoff numbers: 3087.05, 3367.69, 3648.33, 3928.97
Probabilities are derived from option deltas on Bloomberg, There doesn't appear to be any event in the next two weeks sparking a large jump, while investor sentiment that the market is currently overvalued could push it down more then 4%. Also we took into account that the SPX is negatively skewed, making large falls more likely than a normal.
Directly from put option deltas for strikes associated to each move. I priced these with the current ES500 futures, which gave me a price of 3415.

We can try to back this out from options prices as well. We have the following buckets: -12% = 3087
-4% = 3368
+4% = 3648
+12% = 3929 (Using SPY as rough approximation although it trades at a slight discount right now)
SPY 9/21 $309P = 10.2d
SPY 9/21 $337P = 38d
SPY 9/21 $365P = 85d
SPY 9/21 $392P = 91.3d This gives up the distribution above (slightly unweighting the top buckets as spy is down after hours). Will update on Tuesday when markets open.

Similar to the Tesla question, we used the implied probabilities retrieved from the SPX options deltas to retrieve the market implied probability. This is reasonable given that the S&P 500 is very closely monitored by every investor and this market aggregate should cancel out noise from all the underlying models used by the market participants.  Adjustments:
SPX has been at all time highs in last days/weeks, and the majority of the optimism should be already priced in, therefore, given the lack of visible catalysts in the upcoming weeks, there should be very little upside left. As a result, we skewed our distribution more towards the downside risk, bearing in mind that a 12.0% down move would mean the stock price being at 3,078, which the index reached even during Covid, indicating how likely much it would need to take to get to those levels again.

Base rate: I simulated the price of SP500 at time t as a Geometric Brownian motion. For mu the percentage drift and sigma the percentage volatility I used historical returns on different horizons: Jan 1st 19 or Jan 1st 20. For each case, I have then run 10,000 Monte Carlo simulations to get some probabilities for each range -> gives me 5%, 27%, 40%, 22%, 6% in the order of buckets of the question.  Adjustments:
This method is really basic and needs to be balanced (refer to TSLA question for more details). We can use the delta as a proxy of the probability of an option to end in the money.  Currently at 3,426.96 (close 9/4), the different buckets and their implied probabilities by options details [1]. 
Down more than 12.0%, index < 3,087.04 -> 10%
Down between 4.0% and 12.0%, inclusive %: 3,087.04<=index<=3,367.68 -> 27%
Between down less than 4.0% and up less than 4.0% 3,367.68<=index<= 3,648.33 ->58%
Up between 4.0% and 12.0%, inclusive 3,648.33<=index<= 3,928.97 ->5%
Up more than 12.0% index >  3,928.97 ->0%
The 2 methods are in line but the second one has smaller tails and that matched with my current view on the relative stability of short term market (std taken on MC sim can be quite high given the last months vol). [1] https://marketchameleon.com/Overview/SPY/
Sept 4 close = 3,426.96 which is only marginally less, 2.3%, than the  3,508.01 target. Surviving a near rout prior to a 3 day weekend, indicates to me that the market is incredibly solid near term.

I pretty much did the same thing (and will continue to do so) as I did with the TSLA question. I used SPX options data to back out the delta, which is the risk neutral probability under current implied volatility levels that the option will end up in the money. This is a rough heuristic after all (see risk neutral vs. real world probability difference here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_finance) and the delta is best for approximation near the strike. However, since I have no strong prior on this and SPX is reasonable volatile, I am basing my predictions on the market implied (risk-neutral) odds.

Today it is down  1% since 28/AUG and we have good reason to believe it will stay in range. I think there is less downside risk due to recent drops.

Stock closed yesterday 9/3 at 3455.06, while 8/22 close was at 3508, thus we are currently down approximately 1.5%. There are 11 trading days remaining until settlement, 18 days total. Fundamentally, it seems unlikely that there will be a massive change in index prices by 9/22 unless a vaccine is approved. Even then, it is hard to envision the index climbing to 3928, which is what's represented by the 12%+ bucket. Instead, it would likely fall into the 4-12% bucket. Otherwise, I expect markets to continue a slow climb (on average), and thus I put most of my probability into the [-4%, 4%] bucket. I left some probability in the downside bucket (although less than upside since returns are skewed) to represent the downside risk that inevitably exists when dealing with markets.

Given today's big move (Same price as 8/28), we should price in some significant risk of the bubble bursting. We're at record high in terms of valuations. I don't see a major catalyst for SPY to go up more than 4%.

Please notice that I am not using money, just probablities which are "free". With real dollars I'd be more careful.

I usually suck at questions about stock prices, and this means that I have to find a way to improve my current track record with these question. Previously I have tried the combination of recent trend + random walk, which is then properly Montecarlo-ed. This time I am trying a different approach: I decided to finally study the fractal geometry of the stock market. This is not difficult owing to the extensive research about this issue, see for instance [1] for a nice introduction. The point is the following:  1) If Y(t) is the log of a stock price at time t, it will follow a particular probability distribution pattern: < (Y(t+k) - Y(t)) / k^H > ~ follows a stable probability distribution where H is called the Hurst exponent. Actually it is not important what is the probability distribution, as we can determine it later by determining H, then making an histogram and finally dividing by bins. That is, we simply calculate base rates as we always do when applying the outside view, where the only difference with the standard outside view is that we need some theory to determine H. 2) Now the Hurst exponent H is something really interesting:  2.a) For H = 1/2 we have a standard geometric random walk, which is not too predictable unless there is some trend, but it is not too unpredictable either. 2.b) For H > 1/2 we have a trend. This is easy to see, as this exponent increases, it will give rise to a smoother curve with much less zig-zag. If you have studied the idea of a fractal dimension, as H increases, the time dependence of the stock price will approach a fractal dimension of 1, i.e. it will behave as a standard smooth 1-dimensional curve. 2.c) For H < 1/2 it is easy to check that the relative noise increases (relatively) as the time decreases, and as H -> 0 my impression is that the fractal dimension of the stock price will approach 2. The point is that there is extreme noisiness, and this implies that errors are going to be considerable. 3) There are a lot of places where the calculation of H is explained [2,3,4], which means that it is basically a standard procedure, which I will not explain in detail here. 4) Regarding S&P500, the Hurst exponent over the last 256 trading days is about 0.85 and if we limit ourselves to the last 64 days is about 0.83. Do not take my word on it, as this is the first time I use this method and I could have gotten it wrong. However, if my calculation is correct, the trend in S&P500 is more likely to continue than not. And it is also expected to be relatively predictable. By using the Hurst exponents I have calculated, outside-viewing Y(t+k) - Y(t) and then binning I obtained the previous probabilities. There are a few caveats though: I have made a few simplifications when binning (i.e. calculating the base rates) and besides, one can get different probabilities depending on the time span used to calculate these base rates. This means that you should not take this as something particularly more predictive than much more crude methods. 5) So let's cross fingers and see whether with this method I am able to improve my Brier on market quesions.  [1] https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.55.1082&rep=rep1&type=pdf
[2] http://bearcave.com/misl/misl_tech/wavelets/hurst/index.html
[3] https://towardsdatascience.com/how-the-mathematics-of-fractals-can-help-predict-stock-markets-shifts-19fee5dd6574
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurst_exponent#Estimating_the_exponent
At this juncture ppl will be happy with a 4% positive, barring calamity's etc it may be more 3508
